moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. e4 e6 4. Bxc4 Bb4: A quiet, positional opening, befitting the double QP opening moves.
moves.9... Na5 10. Bb3 Nxb3 11. axb3: After a small skirmish, opposite-colored Bishops are left. Already, the sense that a draw could ensue is foreboding. OCB's often do lead to drawish end-game positions.
moves.11... b6 12. c4 Ba6 13. Rc1 Ng6 14. e5 R: Black has gained the advantage of a passed QRP.
moves.17... Bb7 18. h3 Nh4 19. Nxh4 Qxh4: The OCB's are now locked firmly into place as the final minor pieces on the board.
moves.20. Qd3 Qg5 21. f3 a5 22. Rcb1 Ba6 23. R: I tuck my King away, as I have hopes of an attack.
moves.24... Rab8 25. Ree1 Rxb1 26. Rxb1: So much for that idea. Now a long, tense end-game follows.
moves.26... h4 27. Qc2 Qg3+ 28. Kh1 Ra8 29. Kg: More slow maneuvering. Neither side has accomplished much.
Reducing the chances of a tactical surprise, and playing for the OCB ending.
If I don't play this move at once, the Pawn will queen.
moves.44... Kg7 45. Kg3 f6 46. exf6+: I intend to swap off ans many Pawns as possible.
I intend to blockade the black squares.
moves.49... Kg5 50. h4+ Kh5 51. c5: This renders the Black Bishop essentially useless.
moves.51... c6 52. Bc3 g5 53. hxg5 Kxg5 54. Kf: With the K-side resolved, I can slide over to the new theatre of action.
moves.54... Bc2 55. Bb2 Kf5 56. Ke3: As long as I can keep the Black King away from my B, the game will be drawn.
moves.59... Bd5 60. Bb2: Draw agreed, as despite his material advantage Black has no way to make progress.
